Solving a Slider Puzzle Though Machine Learning

Why solve a slider puzzle

If I gave you a 3x3 slider puzzle to solve, you could probably solve it from any amount of shuffling in under a minute. If you tried to explain how to solve it to someone it probably wouldn't take more than a couple more minutes. But if you tried to teach a computer to solve it, the problem changes entirely.

We've probably seen stories of computers playing chess and beating the best players in the world, and we might have heard scary predictions about computers becoming self-aware. But, the idea of a machine learning to do something that we do is a fact of life that excites us and intrigues us, thus the slider puzzle.

The slider puzzle is simple and straight-forward. There are predictable beginnings and endings. It only takes one play. It is scalable and has a very limited set of moves. It is a great candidate as a starting point for machine learning.

what is machine learning

Machine learning is a form programming in which the computer is given a basic parameters regarding the desired task and outcome, but where the computer learns through trial and error better and worse paths and solutions. One example of this many of use on a daily basis is through social media. If your picture is posted on Facebook, you could be tagged my name in the photo without ever writing a word. Facebook knows your face. They've seen your picture so many times that it has become recognizable. Nobody told the computer to tag you, the computer learned the unique curves of your face and decided to suggest that you are indeed the individual in the photo.

With the slider puzzle, we have taught the machine the rules, shown the machine some ways that the game could be solved, and allowed the computer to play over and over again. Over time the machine is able to distinguish between a good move and bad move, resulting in a more efficient path to the solution.
